Bernard Cribbins: Doctor Who and Wombles star dies aged 93

Actor and singer Bernard Cribbins, whose career in TV and film spanned seven decades, dies aged 93.

#2

Like Arthur Lowe, Bernard's voice takes me straight back to childhood from hearing him narrate The Wombles (I have it on CD, of course) and Jackanory where he was possibly my favourite storyteller due to the avuncular warmth in his many appearances.

Outside of these, I suppose I know him best from his two Carry Ons as young romantic lead (he swore when the conveyor belt was throwing the cast round during the climax of Spying and wasn't asked back, which is a shame).

He was a revelation to me on Just A Minute (again, he only did two. And I've only heard his second). Because it's all off-the-cuff it showed a different side to him. He was incredibly quick-witted and sharp, with the puns (and the mints) flying about left, right and centre. A line he fired about washing poppadoms still makes me grin, even though I now forget the exact context. He also had a wonderful chemistry with the cast, including Kenneth Williams, Derek Nimmo and Sheila Hancock.

He worked with Hitch of course, in Frenzy.

Mel O'Drama

He narrated and appeared in so many children's TV shows when I was a child in the 70s and 80s. But The Railway Children and that Fawlty Towers episode are probably his most famous appearances. Apparently he nearly choked in that scene with Basil in the restaurant, You can see him turning red!

Thought i'd post this little known episode of Tales of the Unexpected he was in as well. A fine tribute, and he's hilarious to watch being hypnotised:

James from London

#5

I love the story about the Doctor Who Christmas special ' Voyage of the Damned' which guest-starred Kylie and was also the first episode in which Cribbins appeared. They'd never met, but when she heard his voice at the script read-through, she became strangely emotional and couldn't understand why. Then she realised it was because of The Wombles which she'd watched as a little kid and hearing his voice took her right back there. The Wombles, Jackanory, 'Right Said Fred' and 'Hole in the Ground', which seemed to get played every weekend on Junior Choice (the children's request show on Radio 1), all those Sunday afternoon films like the Carry Ons, Dalek Invasion of Earth, She with Ursula Andress ... he was just always there. And later on, he was really good in a short stint on Coronation Street as a dirty old man who might have potentially fathered Tracey Barlow's baby, and then completely stole the show in the season of Doctor Who where he became a regular.

In one of the DVD commentaries on the Carry On box set, he talks about actors who have died and how he'll see them again "in the bar after the show."

Julia's Gun

#6

That's a lovely Kylie story. I didn't know that.

It's a shame he never had a lead role in a sitcom. He usually appeared as a guest or in a supporting role, often stealing the show. He really deserved to have his own vehicle like Leonard Rossiter in RIsing Damp, or David Jason, and maybe would have become even more famous.

#7

This is very sad news. He had a long and distinguished career but I will always remember him as a stalwart of children's television when I was young. Apart from all the shows mentioned already by forum members, he also presented a long forgotten children's show called Star Turn which I used to loved. It was a kind of quiz show for children with 2 teams of 3 well known celebrities competing against each other. What I particularly liked about the show was the high quality of guests they had on it like the Goodies, the cast of Are You Being Served? or the Carry On actors. It was an era when he was almost always on TV and was a bigger star than many people remember.

#11

Doctor Who and The Wombles actor Bernard Cribbins has died aged 93, his agent has confirmed.

During a career that spanned seven decades, Cribbins narrated the 1970s children's programme The Wombles.

He also played the Doctor's companion Tom Campbell in the second big screen Dr Who movie filmed in 1966 Daleks' Invasion Earth 2150 AD returning 41 years later in the revived TV series.

Cribbins returned to the show as Wilfred Mott, the grandad of Catherine Tate's character Donna.

Obituary: Bernard Cribbins

Bernard Cribbins: A life in pictures

He played Wilfred in Doctor Who from 2007 to 2010.

The actor was known by generations of children - he also played the station porter Albert Perks in the 1970 film The Railway Children. He also had an hilarious appearance in Fawlty Towers as a spoon salesman who Basil Fawlty believed was a Hotel Inspector.

Former Doctor Who showrunner Russell T Davies led the tributes, posting a picture of him on set, while saying: "I'm so lucky to have known him. Thanks for everything, my old soldier. A legend has left the world."

Cribbin's was reprising his role as Wilfred in the 2023 Sixtieth Anniversary season of Doctor Who when he passed away. Our thoughts are with his friends & family & of course his many fan's who have enjoyed his performances on TV & film over the years. May He Rest In Peace.

Last edited: Jul 31, 2022
